newsitem.title: UK: UK Labour denies planning new tax on broadcasters.
newsitem.headline: UK Labour denies planning new tax on broadcasters.

text.p: Britain's opposition Labour Party denied on Wednesday a newspaper report that it was considering introducing a new tax on all broadcasters if it wins the next general election.

A Labour spokesman dismissed a report in the Financial Times that the party was considering introducing a "spectrum tax" on all broadcasters. The report said the tax could be as high as 14 percent of revenue.
The report said that the tax could remove huge discrepancies in what regional ITV companies pay to the Treasury each year for their licences.

The plan would have hit satellite broadcaster BSkyB badly. The Financial Times estimated that it could have cost the company around 134 million stg in the last financial year, swallowing up more than half its pre-tax profits.
BSkyB does not pay mainstream UK corporation tax as it still has substantial tax losses stemming from the start-up of the venture in 1989.

Several ITV companies are unhappy with the amount they pay for their licences. They had to make a cash bid when applying to operate the licences in a 1991 auction and this has led to some glaring anomalies.

Central Television pays a nominal 2,000 stg annually for its licence for the English Midlands while its parent Carlton Communications Plc has to hand over almost 45 million stg to broadcast in the London area.
Central was unopposed in the bidding while Carlton defeated Thames Television to win the London weekday licence.
